summary: In Regina v Kwabena Kwansah, the West African Court of Appeal quashed a manslaughter conviction because the trial judge improperly withdrew from the jury the question of whether a felony had been committed, which was essential to determining whether the killing was justified under section 61(1) of the Criminal Code. The accused claimed he shot the deceased in self-defense after finding him in his home armed with a cutlass and advancing toward him. The judge incorrectly stated there was no evidence of a felony, despite the possibility that the deceased’s conduct constituted a felony under section 310. The court held that the issue of felony was for the jury to decide, and the misdirection undermined the conviction.
rationaleHighlights: It is for the jury to decide whether a felony was committed when assessing justification under section 61(1) of the Criminal Code.
The trial judge erred by stating there was no evidence of felony, thereby withdrawing a key issue from the jury.
The accused’s account of the deceased advancing with a cutlass could constitute a felony under section 310, which the jury should have evaluated.
Due to the misdirection, the conviction for manslaughter could not be upheld.
